name: DeepSeek

score_rationale.persistence: Founded July 2023, ~2.5 years. Rapid development with V3 and R1 models. Young but high-impact.
score_rationale.autonomy: Foundation model enabling agents and applications. Not autonomous itself but enables autonomous systems. R1 reasoning model allows more complex autonomous use.
score_rationale.cultural_impact: 'Sputnik moment' for US AI. Nvidia lost $600B market cap in single day. Chinese open-source AI reaches 30% global usage. Redefined geopolitics of AI.
score_rationale.economic_reality: Trained V3 for $6M (vs GPT-4's $100M). MIT License enables commercial use. High-Flyer hedge fund backing. Cost efficiency changed industry expectations.
score_rationale.governance: MIT License open-source. Chinese company subject to regulations. Research community can examine models.
score_rationale.tech_distinctiveness: Mixture of experts (MoE) architecture. Trained under US chip export restrictions using weaker chips. 10x compute efficiency vs Meta Llama 3.1. R1 matches o1 reasoning.

curator_notes: DeepSeek's January 2025 release of R1 triggered what observers called a 'Sputnik moment' for US AI. The Hangzhou-based company, funded by hedge fund High-Flyer, claimed training V3 for $6M—versus GPT-4's $100M—using weaker chips under US export restrictions. R1's reasoning capabilities match OpenAI's o1 while being fully open-source under MIT license. The announcement crashed Nvidia's stock by $600B in a single day. Yann LeCun (Meta) declared it a 'victory for open-source AI.' Chinese open-source models now represent 30% of global AI usage. DeepSeek fundamentally altered the AI industry's economics and geopolitics.

evidence.claim: V3 trained for $6M vs GPT-4's $100M, 10x efficiency
MIT License open-source, R1 matches o1 reasoning
